posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: I’m trying to simplify some of our code, but I’m unfamiliar with how protobufs work and how to use them to convert objects like Pose2d, Translation2d etc into JSON and back

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked: I’m not sure why you’d want to try this. Protobuf and struct are two size- and time-efficient binary serialization formats. JSON is a textual encoding that’s rather antithetical on both counts. If you really want JSON, you can use Jackson for JSON serialization (I believe most if not all the WPILib math and geometry classes have built in support)

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: I had originally developed this class for transforming various objects to JSON for communication to a coprocessor, but I was told that there is a native way to do this in WPILib.

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked:
See: allwpilib/wpimath/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/math/geometry/struct/Translation2dStruct.java at main · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub

NetworkTables supports struct serialization out of the box. You need to register the struct schema first, but then you can send struct-serializable objects like normal primitives or strings. I think it also supports protobuf, but I can’t recall for sure

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Protobuf is also supported in a near-identical fashion.  The schema is automatically registered for you when you publish a struct or protobuf topic.

Introducing Monologue: Annotation-based Telemetry and Data Logging for Java Teams Programming

link_counts.title: Introducing Monologue: Annotation-based Telemetry and Data Logging for Java Teams

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: What is the difference between using a struct vs protobuf in this case?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: It depends on what you’re trying to do (what the shape of your data is).  Structs are about 3x faster than protobuf, but have a key limitation: they must be a fixed size–e.g. they cannot have internal variable-length arrays.  Conversely, one advantage of structs is they can have a variable-length array at the top level (e.g. the value set to NT); protobufs must be a single message at the top level, any arrays must be internal to that message.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: I think it would be nice to add the struct/protobuf NetworkTables usage to the docs.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Yes, docs for this are on my TODO list…
